detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course is intended for students in their final year (4th or 5th).
If you are an engineering student in: Civil and Geological engineering you will take CIVL 402; Biomedical engineering you will take BMEG 455; Manufacturing engineering you will take MECH 400.

Please use the UBC Directory to find your instructor/TA contact information.

instances.text: ARTH_V 440-B_001 - Seminar in Modern and Contemporary Art (B)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: We will study how real or imagined cities are represented in film, and the ways in which cinematic practices shape perception, social imagination, and the lifeworld. Case studies pair exemplary films and critical texts to explore diverse understandings of place, self, social hierarchies, planetary systems, and models of historical development. Themes include underworlds, homelands, and afterlives; the social production of spaces and natures; concepts of civilization, colonization, and artifice; and conflictual relations between center and periphery, built environments and biomes, sacred and disposable lives.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Shanshui: Landscape (Painting) in China 
Landscape or shanshui painting, literally mountains and water, has been one of the most highly valued artistic practices in China since the eleventh century. Recent scholarship has complicated and refined our understanding of this genre and specifically foregrounded its political functions, highly personalized social meanings, and taken up eco-critical perspectives. In this seminar we will work through recent publications to explore the different forms, meanings, and functions of landscape during specific historical moments and in different social contexts.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: ARTH 479: Performance Actions and Approaches engages a practice-based learning methodology to collectively investigate the activist nature of performance art practices and the varying use of scores as an approach for performance actions. This course looks at how multi-sensory interventions into space shift how we move, hear, see, feel, and exist in relation to others and focuses predominantly on the work of contemporary Indigenous and Black performance artists.

Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous online course. Students are expected to meet online using Zoom on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as online are fully online for the entire term, including exams, and do NOT require any in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to Waitlist and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

instances.text: ASIA_V 476-A_021 - Topics in South Asian Studies (A)
ASIA_V 490-H_021 - Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar (H)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Topic: Seeing Ghosts: Spectral Encounters in Chinese Popular, Literary, and Visual Cultures This 4th year research seminar explores the figure of the ghost in Chinese culture in a variety of representations across time, space, and media. The course asks, "What do ghostsdo?" Students will analyze the changing functions and significance of ghosts at different times and contexts to attempt to answer that question.

Research Course Policy -This course section is restricted to students who have not already completed their 3-credit research course requirement. Students who have previously taken a Research Course may be removed from the course by the department. For more information, please see our Research Course Guidelines. 

Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as in-person are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete. 

Waitlist Policy - All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to Waitlist and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: A capstone research seminar for students in the Interdisciplinary Studies (IDST) program. This course can satisfy the Research Component of the Writing and Research Requirement of the BA degree. This course is restricted to IDST students who have year 4 standing and who do not have ECON as their primary focus. Please submit a registration form to be added into the course.

Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
